subject: Re: [junit] Would JUnit moving to Subversion and/or Google Code have consequences for you?
msgSnippet: Hello, (been around, sorry for the late response) ... at least you can browse the source and download the jars. If somebody wants to contribute it would still
messageBody:
Hello, (been around, sorry for the late response)

David Saff schrieb:

> Actually, it appears that JUnit has already been somewhat blocked from Cuba:
>
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SourceForge#Banned_countries

at least you can browse the source and download the jars. If somebody
wants to contribute it would still be possible to use the maillist or
get in direct contact with a developer.

> Does anyone know for sure if there's a hosting solution that scores 100% on
> Worldwide Access?

I don't know any but I would look for a european hosted one. That way you
should be able to get around US-specific export restrictions.

> Does anyone know what the restrictions involve? (I
> wonder if it's something to do with SSL connections from countries to which,
> theoretically, you can't export SSL-enabling technology, or couldn't at one
> point--I'm very rusty on this).

I'd have to check the SSL-handshake with sourceforge but I assume that
the server is not offering weak cryptography for establishing a SSL-
connection. Not the SSL-technology as such is restricted but the
"strongness". You're only allowed to export/use weak cryptography
like RSA-keys with AFAIR 368 bits or symmetric keys with AFAIR 40 bits.

I'm not sure if these numbers changed in these days (the last time
I was interested in that was 10 years ago), but if you allow a server
to do these kind of "secure" connections nowerdays you might give
other users using a wrong version of a browser a wrong sense of
security, so many server only allow unrestricted cryptography
for the establishment of SSL-connections.

> It appears that if we allow browsing the documentation and downloading
> through junit.org, and other services through Google Code, we'd be offering
> the same level of worldwide access we are now. Is that true?

The browsing of the source at sourceforge is possible without SSL,
so it would be a step back.


Regards, Lothar
